title: Hinkley Point will not become 'bottomless pit' for government cash, vows Chancellor
text:

Tue, Sep 8, 2015, 22:39 BST - UK Markets closed Hinkley Point will not become 'bottomless pit' for government cash, vows Chancellor By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 1 hour 52 minutes ago 0.0001 0.0000 
George Osborne says Britain remains on track to build its first nuclear power plant in more than 20 years, claiming that the country will be left with a 'very big hole' in its electricity needs without the site 
Britain is still on track to build its first nuclear power plant in a generation, the Chancellor has vowed, hitting back at claims the Hinkley Point project would become a “bottomless pit” for the Government’s cash. 
George Osborne claimed that the country would be left with a “very big hole” in its electricity needs without the plant, which is expected to generate around 7pc of Britain’s electricity supplies. 
The Chancellor said he would visit China this month, where he is expected to press for a deal between EDF (Paris: FR0010242511 - news ) , the French developer of Hinkley Point, and potential investment partners in the country. 
He said the Government was fully behind a deal, and described it as a "tragedy" that Britain had stopped building nuclear power stations. 
"I'm pretty confident that we’re going to be able to do a deal, but we’re still in negotiations," he told the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee. 
The Chancellor's comments came just days after EDF's chief executive admitted that the £24.5bn project would not start generating power in 2023 as planned because of a series of delays. 
Mr Osborne said nuclear power stations, including Wylfa in north Wales, would form part of the Government’s energy strategy to “make sure the lights stay on”. 
He said: “The current generation of nuclear power stations are coming to the end of their life, that’s going to create a very big hole in our base electricity supply unless we do something about it ... It’s also important because this country stopped building nuclear power stations, which in my view is a tragedy. This country had the first civil nuclear power stations in the world.” 
Lord Turnbull said the deal, which guarantees EDF a price of £92.50 per megawatt hour, was “incredibly expensive” and a “huge commitment” for the Government. He also highlighted similar concerns over EDF’s nuclear project in Normandy, which faces a five-year setback and escalating costs. 
The crossbench peer suggested that the Government should get back to the “drawing board” rather than “plumping for a bottomless pit and big white elephant”. 
However, Mr Osborne defended the plans and said nuclear energy remained “substantially cheaper than any other low carbon technology”. 
He also described nuclear power as part of Britain’s future energy “mix”, and said other forms of energy such as shale gas would be “complimentary” to nuclear and “not an alternative”. 
Mr Osborne also used the 90-minute session to suggest that Britain would push for an EU treaty change to prevent the UK and other non-eurozone members from becoming isolated in Europe. 
He said the eurozone's recent decision to give Greece a bridging loan using the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (EFSM) during its bail-out talks, of which Britain is the second biggest contributor, suggested that the 19-nation bloc would continue to ride roughshod over EU procedure without a treaty change. 
Mr Osborne said "ad hoc" solutions, such as the “impregnable ringfence" Britain secured from the eurozone for the loan, were not sustainable over the longer term. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) 's a straw in the wind of problems coming our way unless we can deal with this issue," he said.
